dataset_description.json.Name: EEG: First Episode Psychosis vs. Control Resting Task 2
ReferencesAndLinks: Phalen, H., Coffman, B.A., Ghuman, A., Sejdić, E. and Salisbury, D.F., 2020. Non-negative matrix factorization reveals resting-state cortical alpha network abnormalities in the first-episode schizophrenia spectrum. Biological Psychiatry: Cognitive Neuroscience and Neuroimaging, 5(10), pp.961-970., https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/31451387/

Levels.Not_Hispanic: Participant is not of Hispanic Origin
Levels.Unknown: Participant declared their Hispanic Origin to be Unknown

CHANGES:
1.0.0 2021-12-09
  - No changes. First release.
No changes. First release.
README:
Resting EEG and MEG data was gathered for two independently collected samples of healthy and First Episode Psychosis (FEP) individuals.
To obtain resting data, EEG channels were recorded for 5 minutes using an Elekta Neuromag Vectorview system.
EEG was recorded using a low-impedance 10-10 system 60-channel cap. 
The second collected sample of EEG data is provided here. This sample excludes a portion of subjects that have been included with the first acquisition (EEG: First Episode Psychosis vs. Control Resting Task 1), since they were collected using the same montage.
The subjects that have been excluded here and are included in Task 1 are: sub-2140A, sub-2170A, sub-2174A, sub-2176A, sub-2177A, sub-2184A, sub-2193A, sub-2214A, sub-2217A, sub-2221A.

sub-2235A_task-rest_eeg.json.InstitutionName: University of Pittsburgh School of Medicine
sub-2235A_task-rest_eeg.json.ManufacturersModelName: Elekta Neuromag Vectorview with Easycap cap
sub-2235A_task-rest_eeg.json.Instructions: We asked our participants to “Keep eyes open and focus on the centered plus-sign. Let your mind wander, trying not to think about anything in particular and let your thoughts flow freely.”
sub-2235A_task-rest_eeg.json.TaskDescription: In this resting task, participants were asked to let their mind wander while focusing on a fixation point. The fixation point was a plus-sign projected onto a screen in the MEG recording room about 1 meter from the participant.
